section.title: Making content editable
section.p: To edit the content managed by the CMS, several types and brands of editors can (and will) be used. The best way to provide editor connectivity would be to provide an "editor socket", where different editors can plug in. This socket should be generic and as standardized as possible. One way to do this would be to provide an interface based on the MVC design: the content to be edited is presented to the editor as a triplet of xml, xsl and xsd data, representing content, style and structure, respectively. Some more details:

ul.li: Content (XML): This is the content to be edited, and could be an XML, XSL or XSD content, depending on the role of the editor; e.g. the designer, that needs to edit XSL content, will call an editor to edit a stylesheet, and the contents of the stylesheet to be edited are sent to this editor as the Content (or XML) part of the call. As all of XML, XSL and XSD files are actually XML files, this is straightforward.

Style (XSL): This stylesheet will provide information for the representaion of the content in the editor. If the content to be edited is an XML file, this stylesheet might be very similar or even identical to the stylesheet used for "normal" representation of this content, but, in principle, could be something totally different, a stylesheet prepared only for editing purposes, that represents the content of the first file in a way to the editor, that makes most sense for it's editing. An example: if the file (content, the first file in the triplet) to be edited was a stylesheet itself, this stylesheet (style, the second file in the triplet) could be used to group and highlight stylesheet elements visually, to make editing them easier.
Structure (XSD): This file is a schema, providing information about the structure of the content to be edited to the editor, so that the edited contents can be validated.
